abstract.p: This paper proposes as a generalization of isosurfaces, interval ,volume, which is a new type of geometric model representirzg 30 subvolume with field values belonging to a closed interval. A dominant surface fitting algorithm called Murching cubes is extended to obtain Q solid fitting algorithm, which extracts from a given volumetric dataset a high-resolution podyhedral solid data structure of interval volume. Rendering methods for interval volume and principal related operations are also presented. The eflectiveness of this approach is illustrated with a 40 simulated data from atomic collision research. l Well-tuned surface rendering software and geometry engines can be utilized for interactive display and manipulation of isosurfaces. These advantages make SF algorithms still play a complementary role together with DVR algorithms, which can produce more intuitive images of the entire volumetric object, but are inherently computationallyexpensive in spite of many endeavors of optimization.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Turning our eyes to the nature of sampled or simulated datasets reveals that they may have structural ambiguity of the target object, or errors caused by measurement, mathematical modeling or numerical computation.
If we do not take these into account, there may occur some cases where extracted isosurfaces do not have any meaningful information for our exploratory purposes.

Volume visualization is a methodology used for realizing the inner structure and complex behavior of 3D volumetric objects [5, 61. According to Elvins [3], existing volume visualization algorithms fall into two major categories: Surface Fitting (SF) and Direct Volume Rendering(DVR).

SF algorithms extract from a given volumetric dataset, isosurfaces, i.e., contour surfaces with constant-field value, to be rendered geometrically instead of the entire volume, while DVR algorithms project in some way the entire dataset semitransparently onto a 2D screen without any aid of intermediate geometrical primitives.

Since SF algorithms merely visualize a part of the target volumetric object at a time, users might not comprehend the structure and behavior of the object correctly unless they always keep in mind the existence of the unseen remaining part. However, if a spatiallycoherent dataset is given, SF algorithms are known to have the following advantages over DVR algorithms:

For example, it is well known in the biomedical area that boundaries between materials are unequivocal, making it difficult to se ment the regions using a single density value [2, 16 . 'i It has been reported that discrepancy in field values is possible to be induced from organic changes in materials during measurement (e.g., fading effect in confocal microscopy). Also, the limitation of measurement methods could be a principal error source of sampled datasets (e.g., ultrasonography). Needless to say, there is known a wide spectrum of mathematical models for natural phenomena and numerical computation schemes in terms of precision and stability. Therefore, geometrical structures to be extracted from such a volumetric dataset are required to accept an allowance in field values.
l Some quantitative information related to isosurfaces can be easily obtained.
l A set of surface patches is more spatially-efficient than the original lattice structure, establishing an economical volume storage and transmission environment.

This paper proposes a new type of geometric model called Interval Volume, which is a generalization of isosurface with a strict field value, and represents a 3D subvolume with field values belonging to a closed interval. We extend a dominant SF algorithm called Marching Cubes (MC) [7] to obtain a solid fitting algorithm, which extracts from a given volumetric dataset, a high-resolution polyhedral solid data structure of interval volume. Interval volume is used not only for visualizing Region Of Interest (ROI)s with some allowance in their field values, but also for performing the quantitative analysis of ROIs more flexibly than isosurfaces.

(See color plates, page The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In the next section, the definition of interval volume is given, and it is proved that interval volume deserves to be a generalization of isosurface. The interval volume approach is compared with related work in Section 3. Section 4 provides the outline of the solid fitting algorithm using simple 2D examples. Section 5 is devoted to the presentation of interval volume rendering and some representative related operations. Section 6 uses a 4D simulated data from atomic collision research to illustrate the effectiveness of the approach. Section 7 concludes the paper with some remarks on future research directions.

div.head: Related Work
div.p: In order to selectively render a subset of volume which is equivalent to IVD( Q, p), we can choose an alternative approach using DVR, which uses an opacity transfer function having a local support defined over the interval [o, p]. But this approach has the following two drawbacks:
l Because the DVR approach is viewpointdependent, after geometrical operations are executed on a volume, re-projection is needed for visualizing the transformed volume.

l For example, an additional evaluation of rayobject segments makes it possible for the raycasting method to get some quantitative information, such as solid measure and surface area, of interval volume-like regions. However, in general. the obtained values tend to vary according to the direction of viewing rays.

Rather, it should be noted here that the necessity of explicit and compact data structures for fast manipulation and analysis as well as display of volume was already suggested by Udupa, et al., who proposed in their paper [15] th e semiboundary data structure for binary volume data. Also, t,here can be found some similarities between interval volume and Shell data structure [16], which is an extension of the semiboundary to multi-valued volume data. Shell is a structural model for representing fuzzy boundaries between adjacent materials, and defined as a subvolume each cube of which satisfies together with its neighbors a certain condit,ion relevant to a closed interval of assigned opacity. But there can be observed the following three differences between interval volume and shell:
The main purpose of shell is limited to the reduction of spatial complexity and fast manipulation of volumes containing fuzzy boundaries.
Since shell rendering is performed in a cube-bycube manner. we can obtain precise visualization results only when the resolutions of volume and pixel plane are almost of the same order.
The interval volume extraction algorithm, which will be described in the next section, could be extended to structured(non-axis-aligned hexahedral) volumetric datasets.

div.head: Extracting
div.p: Interval Volume

In this section, we extend the MC al f orithm ['i] so as to extract an interval volume Ir/, a,/J) from a given volumetric dataset Vo. Let us assume that the basic MC algorithm is modified with an auxiliary algorithm, such as Asymptotic Decider(AD) [ll], for resolving some ambiguities in polygonal patch configuration.
There are two alternatives to extend the MC algorithm.

One is to use the combination of threevalued classification (below interval; inside interval; and above interval) of eight vertex voxels of each cube for determining a proper polyhedral block pattern of interval volume. The total number of classified voxel combination equals 6,561 (=38). As in the case of the original MC algorithm, rotational and mirroring symmetries could be taken into account to reduce the number to a certain degree. However, we can not ignore that the AD sub-algorithm increases the final number of polyhedral block patterns.

Alternatively, in this paper, we take advantage of set operations on special interval volumes. Briefly speaking, to yield IVL)(CY, ,/3)? we first generate for each cube the polyhedral blocks representing IVo (a, d,,,) and Ib(&in, P), and then calculate the intersection of those blocks. Hereafter, the former is called o-cube, and the latter P-cube.

The number of polyhedral block patterns for both special cubes is the same as that of polygonal patch patterns in the original MC algorithm. Therefore. the computational complexity of the interval volume extraction algorithm is expected to be in the same order O(N) as that of the MC algorithm.
Below, the interval volume extraction algorithm is described in more detail from the viewpoints of its local procedure and global consideration.

div.head: Global Consideration
div.p: Now, let us shift our focus int.o the problem of topological consistency of polyhedral blocks for interval volume in adiacent cubes. We can show that nolvhedral blocks are always connected consistently, be& fitting from the AD sub-algorithm (Fig. 5). The right cube is the same as in Fig. 4, while the left cube has a different polyhedral block pattern from the right cube. The number 0 beside the vertex at the lower-left corner means that the voxel's field value is within the interval [a, p].

An analysis of the nature of the trilinear interpolation scheme I reveals that whenever a cube has a face-connected neighbor, the patches on the shared boundary of the cubes are omissible (Fig. 5). If we do not delete such a boundary patch, the total number of patches becomes O(iV) in the worst case, spoiling the effect of relatively low complexity in the geometric approach to volume visualization. Furthermore, by transitively decimating nontrivial (non-coaxial) coplanar patches, we can obtain the necessary and sufficient set of polyhedral blocks for representing interval volume in the entire volumetric dataset. This operation is an extension of the triangle patch decimation for isosurfaces [13].

div.head: Interval Volume Rendering and Operat ions
div.p: This section describes the rendering methods for interval volume and three principal operations on interval volume: focusing; solid operations; and morphological measurements.

div.head: Rendering
div.p: Interval volume can be displayed as an opaque solid. The normal vector of an IV0 patch is interpolated using I from field gradients at eight vertex voxels of a cube to which the patch belongs [7]. So the conventional smooth shading methods are applicable to the display of IV,.
Considering that IV, also retains field values of VD in its internal region including boundaries, we can use color transfer function to attach colors onto the boundaries of IVo(a,/3).

Note that in a case that IVD does not intersect the outer boundaries of VD, we can see the only single colored boundary of IVD as far as the trilinear interpolation scheme is used as 1. To explore IV, topology, it is effective to display the hidden internal boundary simultaneously by making the external boundary semi-transparent.
Of course, in a case that IV' intersects the outer boundaries of VD, we have to visualize the change in field values on the boundaries based on the color transfer function.

Furthermore, IV0 could be volumetrically rendered instead of I'D to peer into the change in field values inside Iv,. In this case, the number of voxels to be traversed is considerably decreased, making the rendering faster. If this method is applied to Tipg,?f shown in Fig. 1, more smooth concentrically spherical field distribution would be visualized.

div.head: Interval
div.p: Volume Operations (a) Focusing One of the meaningful navigating operations on interval volume is focusing, which controls the length of the interval to make interval volume approach the target isosurface. When errors in field value of a given volumetric dataset are relatively large, it is sufficient to obtain an interval volume wit.h an appropriate allowance.

As described in Section 3, the effect of focusing could be obtained by the control of the local support of opacity transfer function in DVR. However, users in general may want to modify their viewpoints through the course of exploration. Recalculation of viewpointdependent DVR requires O(N), while the geomet.rical transformation and re-rendering of II/o are expected to require only O(N2i3).
(b) Solid operations Here, three representative solid operations on IVD are described.

a Cutting operation We can cut IV, along an arbitrary plane. Coloring the cross-section allows us to directly explore the inner structure of ROI specified with IVD. 0 Composition of multiple interval volumes When we want to construct IV0 having multiple intervals, we can first construct an IV, for each single interval, and then take the union of them.

l Efficient multi-scalar volume visualization It is very important to investigate mutual relationships among fields of a multi-scalar volumetric dataset. One possible way is to perform DVR with respect to some field efficiently within a ROI specified with IVo for another field.

(c) Morphological measurements Quantitative measurement is indispensable for better understanding of the target objects. IvD is a geometric model which is also suitable for several measurements such as surface area and solid measure. Actually, the surface area of IV0 can be calculated by summing up all the surface areas of polyhedral patches. In the current implementation which will be described in the next section, the solid measure of II'D are calculated by count,ing subcubes which are generated using an octree-like subdivision of cubes. The depth of subdivision is up to three for the sake of temporal efficiency. A similar method is used to calculate numerically the field integral D(a, p) wit,hin interval volume IV(a, ,9) at a precision that subvoxel structure is linearly approximated: from which, we can derive the field average over the ROI, providing a navigat.ing information for fast focusing. Moreover field deviation could be used as a measure of volumetric spatial coherence.

div.head: Proton-Hydrogen Atom Collision
div.p: To illustrate the effectiveness of the interval volume approach, we chose simulated 4D data of proton (H+) -hydrogen atom (H) collision, which is a simple ionatom collision problem, but very important in that the problem has a wide spectrum of applications such as nuclear fusion, material sciences and radiology. The purpose here is to investigate how the incident proton affects the behavior of an electron around the target hydrogen atom.

Suppose that a proton comes into collision with a hydrogen atom with relative velocity ZI = 1 atomic unit.s 2 and that the impact parameter b is set to 0.1 atomic units 3 (Fig. 7). The setting of these parameter values makes the problem fall into the category of intermediate energy collisions, and thus we can adopt a well-known semi-classical approximation to formulate the governing equations for the phenomenon. The details of the formulation can be found in [12]. Conventionally, the physicists have explored the collision problem by plotting 2D graphs of the simulated time-varying transition probabilities for each orbital. However, such a graph forces the physicists to imagine how the collision occurs in 3D. Instead, we will get a comprehensive illustration of the simulated collision by visualizing the distorted electron density distribution volumetrically. Fig. 8 shows nine snapshots excerpted from an animation of the collision simulation.

The numerical computation was done on a Stardent TITAN 3OOOV system (CPU: R3000 x2, Clock: 32MHz; RAM: 64MByte). It took approximat,ely almost one day to get lo4 time steps of 61 x 61 x 61 volumet,ric datasets. Each snapshot was visualized with interval volume IV~(90,120) 4, whose low (outer) densitv boundary is semi-transparently rendered. The rendering was done on an SGI Indy system (CPU: R4000, Clock: 100MHz; RAM: 64MByte). For getting each snapshot, it took just a second.
The proton is coming from the left side into the visualization domain.

It is easily observed that a time-varying distortion of electron density distribution around the hydrogen atom was induced by the positive charge of the marching proton. Fig. 9 illustrates four typical interval volume images of the 4th volume dataset in Fig. 8, which are rendered using the methods described in Section 5.1. Through the intensive use of these methods, we can get more meaningful information from each of the datasets.

div.head: Concluding Remarks
div.p: This paper has extended the concept of surface fitting, and presented interval volume as a generalized geometric model for indirect volume visualization. Major contributions of this paper include: Figure 10: Interval volume specified with electron existence possibility.
l An MC-based solid fitting algorithm to construct interval volume from a given volumetric dataset was developed.

l Interval volume display and analysis methods were presented. In particular, interval volume can make visualization and measurement reliant on each other, achieving a more sophisticated volume realization environment.

To make interval volume extraction algorithm faster and interactively usable for larger volumetric datasets. we can take advantage of e.xisting op-Gmization a proaches to the MC algorithm, such as parallelism [4 : P discretization[lO]; adaptive mesh size determination:
and hierarchical min-max spatial indices such as BON0 [17].

n-e are now considering the applicability of interval volume to a particular medical application problem to explore 3D brain in MetachromaGc Leukodystrophy, where the focusing capability is expected to play an important role in specifying scattered accumulation of lipid in cerebral cells [14].
